intro: Camissonia luciae, commonly known as the Sierra foothill daisy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its small, white to pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It has a short, hairy stem and produces small, oval-shaped leaves. Camissonia luciae is often found in California and is known for its delicate appearance and ecological importance to local pollinators.
